attributes.title: First Appearance in Provincial Court
attributes.description: If you have been arrested and charged, but were not kept in custody, you will have an upcoming First Appearance in Alberta Provincial Court.

contentBlocks.sectionContent:
**Keep scrolling to learn about:**

- Contacting an NCSA Courtworker 
- Before Court
- The Day of Court
- Fun Facts: Don’t Just Plead Guilty!

Plus, if you get all the way down to the bottom of the page, take Raven’s UnQuiz for some sweet, and free, BearPaw U Swag!

[Native Counselling Services of Alberta](http://ncsa.ca) (NCSA) Courtworkers can help Indigenous people with upcoming appearances in Alberta court. The best-case scenario is to Contact an NCSA Courtworker at least a week before your appearance. 
You may also find a Courtworker, or if you prefer, a Duty Counsel Lawyer, at the courthouse on the day of court. 

# Duty Counsel

Duty Counsel is a FREE Lawyer at the courthouse for that day only.
Ask a clerk at the front counter if you need help finding them. 
Remember, Courtworkers, Duty Counsel Lawyers and other Court staff are busy and have many community members to help on court day so please be patient.

contentBlocks.tipText: Did you know if you live in a remote community and transportation to court is an issue, an NCSA Courtworker may be able to appear for you during your first appearance. Contact an NCSA Courtworker to find out.

contentBlocks.sectionContent:
It is always best to meet _at least a week before court_ with your Courtworker, or if you have one, a Lawyer, to better understand: 

- What the charge is
- Is there jeopardy of jail time? If so, **Apply for Legal Aid** or consider hiring a lawyer
- How might the outcome affect your life
- Restorative or Alternative Justice Options

# Who can help you in court?

- Be a _**Lone Wolf**_ and go it alone, this is called self-representing (not recommended)
- An _**NCSA Courtworker**_ is FREE and can explain options, appear with, and even speak for you in court. Although if a Judge asks you a question, always look at and answer the Judge directly
- _**Duty Counsel**_ is a FREE Lawyer at the courthouse for **_that day only_**. Ask a clerk at the front counter to help direct you to Duty Counsel
- Hire your own _**Lawyer**_

If you were arrested and charged with a criminal offence in Alberta, you will have been given a _First Appearance Notice_ or a _Promise to Appear_.  This document will have information about the charge and the time/location of your court date. Remember to bring your _Promise to Appear_ to court with you on the day. 

**Get to the courthouse early**, then:

- Find the _**Docket**_ in the lobby area. The docket is a list of names appearing in court that day 
- Look for your name and any information about Courtroom number/location/time
- Find your NCSA Courtworker, Lawyer, or Duty Counsel Lawyer
- If you are a _**Lone Wolf***_, go to the correct courtroom and sit quietly in the gallery until your name is called. Learn more about Self-Representing here (not recommended).

If you can’t find the docket, courtroom, a Courtworker or Duty Counsel Lawyer, just ask a _**clerk at the front counter**_, they are all very helpful.
Please note that Courtworkers and Duty Counsel Lawyers may be in court helping other community members so be patient.

*If you are considering being a Lone Wolf, we would ask you to reconsider, join the pack, and **[Contact](https://ncsa.ca) an NCSA Courtworker**

contentBlocks.tipText:
If you have a traffic ticket, go to the front counter and ask them where to deal with it. Minor traffic tickets can usually be dealt with right there at the front counter. Don’t sit in court all day waiting for your name to be called with a traffic ticket. 
An NCSA Courtworker may be able to get your traffic ticket lowered or even thrown out.  Contact them beforehand to arrange a meeting. 
There are some serious criminal charges, called Indictable Offenses, that an NCSA Courtworker may not be able appear with you for.  However, they can help connect you with a Duty Counsel Lawyer or provide support in Applying for Legal Aid. 

Legal Aid Alberta provides affordable legal services and is NOT FREE.  See if you may qualify.
contentBlocks.tipTitle: BearPaw Tip for U - Don’t Just Sit in Traffic!

contentBlocks.sectionContent:
Arrive in the courtroom at least 15 minutes before the time on your Promise to Appear.  Whether it is a Closed-Circuit TV Courtroom, or an actual courtroom, people are usually called up in alphabetical order by last name.  So, you may need to wait a while if your last name starts with “W”. 

Sit quietly in the public gallery at the back of the courtroom. When they call your name, come up to the podium. If you have a Courtworker or Lawyer, they will look back in the gallery and quietly acknowledge you to come up. They will stand by your side and address the court for you. 

Sometimes the judge will ask you a direct question. Look at and answer the judge. Stand up tall and speak clearly. Showing respect to the judge and the court shows them that you a likely to follow court orders and instructions.

contentBlocks.tipText:
- Be on time
- Dress to show respect to the judge and court
- Take your hat off  
- Turn off your cell phone
- Stay quiet
- Stand when the judge comes in

contentBlocks.sectionContent:
# Don’t Just Plead Guilty!

Don’t just Plead Guilty to the charge just to get the whole process over with. There are serious consequences to pleading guilty, including a criminal record. 

Take the time to know your options, see if the case against you is accurate, and have a choice in what is happening to you. You can ask the judge to Reserve your Plea and Adjourn your appearance to give you time to seek legal advice.

**Reasons** people may quickly plead guilty may include:

- Feeling intimidated by the justice system and lawyers 
- Afraid to ask questions and don’t want to say, “I don’t understand” 
- Police have said there’s no point fighting the charge
                            

>“Plead guilty because it’s only a fine? Yeah, you can pay that. But that’s not the problem.  The problem is that you’re going to have a criminal record and deal with that for the rest of your life.”
 
 -NCSA Courtworker-

Pleading guilty to a criminal charge will result in a criminal record and:  

- May hurt opportunity to travel to the United States or elsewhere
- Sometimes you can't get a particular job with a criminal record

Learn more about Criminal Records here. <need link>

If you plead _Not Guilty_ at your First Appearance, the judge will want to set a trial date. If you don’t have a lawyer at this time, it is recommended you ask the judge to _Reserve your Plea_ (not decide yet) so you can have time to find a lawyer.  You don’t want to plead Not Guilty, have the judge set a trial date and then find out later that your lawyer is not available that day.

The Crown Prosecutor represents the government of Alberta in the case against you. The First Appearance is an opportunity to communicate with the “Crown” and find out what they are seeking and if there is _jeopardy of jail_.

If you are in jeopardy of going to jail, it’s recommended you hire a lawyer or Apply for **Legal Aid**.

_Legal Aid Alberta_ provides _affordable legal services_ and is NOT FREE. [See if you may qualify](https://www.legalaid.ab.ca/questions/).
 
 NCSA Courtworkers have good relationships with Crown Prosecutors and can:

- Speak to them on your behalf and see if the Crown Prosecutor has an offer. This offer may be a sentence, reduction in charge, fine or restorative justice/alternative measures (Greg to confirm with legal/NCSA)
- Sometimes, the Crown’s offer can be the best outcome

# Common Outcomes of a First Criminal Court Appearance

Whether you have a Courtworker, Lawyer or are representing yourself, here are some common outcomes of a first appearance:  

- _**Reserve your Plea**_ if you need more time to get legal help or decide what to do
- Plead _**Not Guilty and set a trial date**_
- Plead _**Guilty**_ to the charge and move to _Sentencing_
- Order _**Disclosure**_ of evidence of the case against you. This may include police reports and other evidence. You have a legal right to review the _Disclosure_ and see if it is accurate

contentBlocks.sectionTitle: Real World Tips for Applying for Legal Aid
contentBlocks.sectionContent:
_Applying for Legal Aid starts with a phone call:_

- Call at 8:15am in the morning. If you phone any later in the day, you may be on hold for a very long time
- Find a stable _landline phone connection_. If your cell phone drops the call after you’ve been on hold for 45 minutes, or you run out of minutes, you have to start all over. Ask your Courtworker if a stable landline phone connection is available in your community

[See if you may qualify](https://www.legalaid.ab.ca/questions/)

Getting charged with a crime and appearing in court is a difficult and stressful time in life.  It can also be a time to begin to look at yourself and make changes for the better. 

Talk to your NCSA Courtworker if you are interested in healing or _Restorative Justice Programs_. 

An NCSA Courtworker is experienced in understanding: 

- What happened? 
- What were the circumstances that brought you to court?
- Are there opportunities for programs, support, or healing?

**Even if you’ve been charged with a crime, you still matter**. You are a human being. People make mistakes and you still have choices.  

It is also important to understand that as Indigenous people, due to Canada’s history of colonization and racism, we all suffer from some level of trauma in our lives. 

Issues like mental health, violence and addictions bring our people to court every day. 

Many of these issues in our community are a direct result of colonization and the residential school system. Children were removed from their parents and inter-generational cycles of trauma and cultural genocide occurred. Watch **NCSA’s Documentary Home Fire** to learn more.

For over 50 years, NCSA has been helping Indigenous people in court and supporting them in their healing journey. NCSA Courtworkers are guided by the **NCSA’s Model of Resilience** and its foundation of:
- Self Determination
- Relationships
- Connectedness

There are many different **Restorative Justice Programs** available across the province. These programs may also be known as Alternative Measures or Extra Judicial Sanctions.  

These programs may include Indigenous processes that bring the victim and offender together to learn about impacts of the crime, consequences, and healing going forward.  

The Crown Prosecutor and the Judge would have to agree to _divert your case away from court_ and into a _Restorative Justice Program_.  Often, if you successfully complete the program, charges may be dropped, a criminal record avoided, and healing on the way. 

**Contact an NCSA Courtworker** to see if you are a good candidate for a Restorative Justice Program.

contentBlocks.Question: 1.	When is the best time to contact an NCSA Courtworker if you have an upcoming first court appearance?

Answers.Answer: At least week before the court date
Just show up at court and hope they aren’t busy
It is the notice the police give you after being arrested
A list of names appearing in court that day
A saying used by front desk clerks about your bank account when you pay a fine, “Docket!”

contentBlocks.Question: When you appear in court, it is important to:

Answers.Answer: Dress to show respect to the court and judge

contentBlocks.Question: What are some common reasons why Indigenous people might just plead guilty criminal charges without exploring all their options?

Answers.Answer: Feeling intimidated by the justice system and lawyers
Afraid to ask questions and don’t want to say, “I don’t understand”
Police have said there’s no point fighting the charge
